Joseph Fox has dedicated over twelve years to working as a care worker, following a diverse career path prior to that. Divorced and the proud father of four children and three grandchildren, Fox's personal experiences have shaped his commitment to public service and political activism. Joseph Fox's political awakening began during the Maastricht Treaty era. Disillusioned by the European integration project, he reached out to Sir George Gardiner, then MP for Reigate, pledging his support if Gardiner opposed the Treaty. Gardiner's alignment with Fox's views and his subsequent vote against the Treaty deepened Fox's resolve. His pride in supporting Gardiner in 1997 was unparalleled, marking a significant moment in his political journey. Fox's engagement with the Campaign for an Independent Britain, a coalition of EU-realists from various political backgrounds, further clarified his stance on European integration. He quickly recognized that the major political parties were firmly committed to the European Project, leaving little room for dissent within their ranks. Joining UKIP in 1999 marked a pivotal moment in Joseph Fox's political career. Over the years, he has consistently stood in elections, with annual candidacies from 2000, multiple runs in 2009, and numerous close calls with victory. Despite the challenges and setbacks, Fox's perseverance has only strengthened his resolve. He humorously notes that while he has yet to win an election, his near victories this year demonstrate significant progress. Fox attributes some of his recent success to the national swing toward UKIP, but he also credits his extensive local campaigning and media presence for establishing a solid local reputation. His efforts have garnered recognition and support from constituents, reflecting his dedication to the cause and his ability to connect with the community. Fox believes that expanding the party's appeal to former Labour supporters is crucial. He highlights the abandonment of traditional Labour values by New Labour and the resulting disillusionment among many who once trusted in the promises made by Jacques Delors. Fox emphasizes that while the EU is not solely responsible for the economic difficulties faced by many, it has played a significant role. His canvassing efforts reveal a substantial base of support among those affected by economic stagnation, underscoring UKIP's potential beyond its traditional conservative base. Joseph Fox remains steadfast in his commitment to honesty in politics. He asserts that truth is the most powerful weapon against political adversaries, and he pledges to maintain transparency and integrity in his representation of the constituency.

Daniel Dabin is standing as the Reform UK candidate for Rochester and Strood in the upcoming 2024 United Kingdom General Election. With a commitment to challenging the political status quo, Dabin aims to represent the voices of local residents who feel let down by the traditional two-party system. He is competing against six other candidates, bringing his expertise and Reform UK's bold vision for Britain to the forefront of the election. As a dedicated member of Reform UK, Daniel Dabin supports the party's mission to introduce practical and people-focused policies that address key national issues. Reform UK positions itself as a common-sense alternative to the Conservative and Labour parties, advocating for changes in immigration control, economic policy, healthcare, law enforcement, and democratic reform. Reform UK proposes a strict freeze on non-essential immigration to reduce pressure on housing, public services, and wages. Daniel Dabin supports the party's strategy to combat illegal immigration through detention and deportation measures, as well as the elimination of health tourism and immediate benefit access for new arrivals. Dabin backs Reform UK's tax reduction plan, which aims to boost disposable income for working-class citizens and support small businesses. Key initiatives include raising the personal income tax threshold, cutting corporation tax for SMEs, and abolishing unnecessary business taxes to encourage investment and economic expansion. A strong advocate for healthcare reform, Daniel Dabin supports Reform UK's commitment to eliminating NHS waiting lists and introducing tax incentives for medical professionals to address staffing shortages. The party also promotes leveraging private healthcare options to ease NHS burdens, potentially introducing a patient voucher system for quicker treatment. Reform UK takes a critical stance on the UK's Net Zero policies, citing economic concerns. Dabin aligns with the party's push to revive domestic oil and gas production, minimize reliance on renewable energy subsidies, and explore nuclear technology without the constraints of current environmental regulations. Public safety is a top priority for Daniel Dabin and Reform UK. The party's crime policies include increasing police recruitment, enforcing zero-tolerance measures against violent crime, and streamlining the deportation of foreign criminals. Additionally, Reform UK advocates for mandatory life sentences for repeat violent offenders and increasing funding for the justice system. Reform UK's political vision includes major constitutional changes. Dabin supports the party's call to leave the European Convention on Human Rights, restructure the House of Lords, and implement a proportional representation voting system to enhance political accountability and fairness. Daniel Dabin's candidacy reflects Reform UK's dedication to radical and effective reform across multiple sectors. His campaign emphasizes policies that prioritize British sovereignty, cultural integrity, economic resilience, and national security. As the 2024 General Election approaches, Dabin is committed to advocating for the transformative policies that Reform UK believes will create a more prosperous and secure future for Britain. As a dedicated candidate for Rochester & Strood, committed to transforming the political landscape by challenging the outdated legacy parties that have hindered progress in our nation. His focus will be on advocating for fundamental freedoms, enhancing healthcare services, and strengthening Britain's economic and military capabilities to ensure robust national defense. Brings a unique perspective to politics, combining his experience as a businessman with a background in the military. His understanding of the crucial role SMEs play in driving economic growth is complemented by his awareness of the importance of a strong national deterrent, gained from his military service. Acutely aware of the pressing need for more healthcare professionals in the area. He recognizes that while the current MP and Council focus on expanding housing developments, they overlook the critical need for additional GPs, doctors, nurses, and dentists. The proposed influx of 80,000 new housing units threatens to exacerbate social issues and strain existing infrastructure, making it imperative to address these concerns. : Advocating for an increase in frontline NHS staff, reducing middle management, and focusing on improving patient outcomes. He will push for the establishment of a dedicated cancer treatment hospital to meet the highest international standards.

Paul Barrett is honored to be chosen as the Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Reform UK in Romsey and Southampton North. Furthermore, Barrett highlights the inadequate support for veterans compared to the focus on illegal migrants. : Introducing a credible tax policy by raising the income tax threshold to £20,000, aimed at encouraging young people to enter the workforce and attract individuals to the farming sector.

As a lifelong resident deeply embedded in the fabric of Runnymede & Weybridge, Stewart Mackay brings a unique blend of community spirit and unwavering dedication to the forefront of local politics. James Milmine believes that democracy functions optimally when voters are presented with real choices and when the parties in power are committed to fulfilling their promises. Unfortunately, the Labour and Conservative parties have repeatedly demonstrated a disconnect between their promises and their actions. Their failure to deliver on their pledges is compounded by an electoral system that perpetuates their dominance, leaving the electorate feeling disenfranchised. The current system prioritizes maintaining the status quo of these two major parties, who are primarily concerned with retaining power at any cost. This has led to a narrative where voting for smaller parties is dismissed as a "wasted vote," signaling a deeper issue within our electoral framework. Milmine argues that this system is fundamentally flawed and demands comprehensive reform to ensure that every vote has meaningful impact. In the Sevenoaks area, frustration is growing due to the government's failure to address key issues such as road safety, accessible healthcare, and reliable public transportation. Instead, the focus appears to be on less pressing matters like banning certain dog breeds and smoking. Additionally, the burden of policies like ULEZ, LTN, and rising fuel duties disproportionately affects those who depend on their vehicles for essential work. Milmine is deeply concerned about the multiple crises facing the nation, including energy, housing, immigration, health, and economic challenges. He criticizes the current leadership for exacerbating these issues and believes that the party responsible for the financial collapse 14 years ago is not suited to fix these problems. Reform UK, according to Milmine, represents a genuine alternative. He aligns with Albert Einstein's view that repeating the same actions and expecting different results is irrational. Milmine believes Reform UK's focus on pragmatic solutions and common sense can address major issues such as road maintenance, healthcare waiting times, affordable housing, crime reduction, and economic revitalization. With 16 years of experience as a pilot in the RAF, Milmine has lived and worked across England, Scotland, and Wales, strengthening his commitment to the Union. He is passionate about preserving the unity of the UK and is dedicated to representing the hardworking people of the Sevenoaks constituency. Milmine is prepared to bring his resilience and determination to the forefront of his efforts to mend a fractured country.

William Fotheringham-Bray is a 23-year-old emerging filmmaker and community advocate based in Sittingbourne and Sheppey. Alex Culley is the Reform UK Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Southampton Itchen, bringing a strong commitment to political reform, cultural preservation, and economic stability. John Edwards supports Reform UK's forward-thinking policies aimed at positively impacting everyone's income. By raising the tax threshold to £20,000, individuals in low-paid employment would see immediate financial relief. Additionally, reducing VAT on energy bills and lowering fuel duty would help to curb inflation, providing economic benefits to both consumers and businesses. Lowering corporation tax from its current 25% would make the UK more attractive to foreign investment and manufacturing, fostering a more stable and prosperous future. Edwards advocates for a modernized immigration system that selects individuals based on their potential contribution to the nation. A system requiring valid health insurance and specific employment skills would ensure that newcomers are well-prepared to contribute effectively. This approach contrasts sharply with current practices, highlighting Reform UK's commitment to a pragmatic immigration policy. John Edwards stands firmly behind Reform UK's robust plan to address illegal migration. Unlike the Conservatives, who have failed to act decisively, or Labour, which has agreed with Brussels to fly migrants into the UK, Reform UK is dedicated to stopping illegal crossings and returning individuals to France. Edwards supports the strategic reduction of foreign aid to focus on rebuilding essential public services that have suffered from chronic underfunding. Redirecting these resources would help restore and enhance critical services for the benefit of all citizens. Reform UK's vision for the NHS includes redistributing finances to improve the training and retention of doctors. Edwards believes that eliminating wasteful management roles, such as diversity and equality officers, would free up funds for patient care. Reform UK envisions a unified nation where healthcare reform removes unnecessary barriers, such as degree entry for nurses, to attract more individuals into the profession. John Edwards supports the development of an affordable and integrated transport system to reduce road congestion and pollution. He believes that petrol and diesel vehicles should remain in use until viable alternatives are fully developed and available. Edwards is committed to rebuilding the UK's armed forces, which have been diminished to dangerously low levels under successive Tory governments. Reform UK aims to restore the military's capability to effectively address overseas threats and safeguard national security.

Rory O'Brien was born in Sligo, Eire, to Anglo-Irish parents and moved to the UK in the late 1970s. Rory O'Brien's political journey began with the grassroots campaign team for the Brexit Party in Spelthorne during the 2019 General Election. His concern over the severe Covid-19 lockdown measures and the prevailing group-think in Westminster motivated him to take direct action. Rory first ran for office in the 2021 Surrey County Council elections for Sunbury Common & Ashford Common, securing 4% of the vote. He built on this with a 7% share in the 2022 by-election for Spelthorne Council's Sunbury Common seat and achieved an 11% share in the 2023 Local Election. Rory O'Brien is a passionate advocate for national reforms, supporting the principles of 'small government' that prioritize oversight while encouraging free expression, freedom of movement, freedom of choice, and free-market values. His dedication to these ideals reflects his belief in addressing the limitations of the current political system. Standing for Reform UK, Rory aims to challenge the entrenched political duopoly and improve representation. His commitment to meaningful change underscores his desire to offer a fresh perspective in the political landscape.

She highlights the challenges faced by educators due to outdated pay structures and bureaucratic constraints, stressing the need for reform to address the evolving needs of students. With a background in secondary state education, Samantha is dedicated to ensuring that education meets the highest standards and addressing other local issues. She is passionate about driving reform in the UK and believes that Reform UK is uniquely positioned to challenge the status quo. Samantha calls for collective action to achieve meaningful change and urges voters to support Reform UK for a transformative shift in the political landscape.

A 2022 report from Buckinghamshire Healthcare NHS Trust highlights that the hospital will be "not fit for use in the next 5 years." If elected, Richard is committed to lobbying Westminster for a complete rebuild rather than temporary fixes. Richard acknowledges the widespread issue of homelessness in Wycombe, which extends beyond those sleeping rough to include individuals couch-surfing or living in temporary accommodation. Local charities, like Wycombe Homeless Connection, strive to assist those in need, but without substantial national change, their efforts remain challenging. Richard believes that tackling the rising cost of living is essential, advocating for policies such as abolishing energy bill VAT and raising the income tax threshold. He envisions collaboration between central government, local authorities, and charities to eradicate homelessness in the area. Wycombe's strategic location offers excellent connectivity to both London and Birmingham, complemented by a diverse industrial base. Richard sees potential in transforming the town's high street into a vibrant cultural hub. As MP, he plans to establish a task force that will engage with local stakeholders and organizations, such as the High Wycombe Regeneration Board and the Thames Valley Chamber of Commerce. The goal is to attract retailers and restaurants, enhancing the high street's appeal and competitiveness with neighboring towns like Beaconsfield and Marlow. With his unique blend of professional experience and libertarian principles, Jamie Pullin stands out as a transformative candidate within Reform UK. Despite a significant increase in minimum wage, the tax-free threshold remains unchanged, leading to higher effective tax rates. I am a solicitor and I care passionately about our people and our quality of life. My key priorities for our region are employment, health, wellbeing and social care, transport, crime, the environment, and you. Local businesses are being severely affected by the introduction of 'Low Traffic Neighbourhood schemes', 'Clean Air Zones', imposed road closures and arbitrary traffic restrictions, all of which reduce public access to their businesses. These schemes also make travel around our towns and cities unnecessarily difficult. I will change these detrimental measures, invest in our town centres and revitalise our high streets to allow our businesses to flourish and thrive, and seek to encourage more businesses to invest in the West Midlands. Much is spoken about the drive to Net Zero and the negative impact of pollution on the environment. Energy policies pursued across the region are making everyone poorer and colder as a result of soaring fuel prices and green energy levies. inflating our energy costs. West Midlands water companies discharged untreated sewage into our waterways over 60,000 times during 2023, a 54% increase in the number of sewage spills over 2020-2022. Measures must be taken to stop this practice, clean up our rivers and waterways and prosecute offenders. Excessive shareholder profit-taking must be stopped, and the money invested into reducing leaks, developing the water infrastructure, and combating pollution. As predicted, HS2 has proved to be the white elephant we all thought it would be. It was heralded as the stimulus for transport and travel in the West Midlands, but has failed to deliver any tangible benefits, leaving a trail of destruction and devastation to the countryside in its wake. Instead of vanity projects, we need a complete rethink on travel to deliver a fully integrated, efficient, safer and more effective transport system for the West Midlands. Crime is on the increase, particularly violent crime, with the West Midlands being one of the highest crime areas in the country. More measures are needed, as well as an increase in police officers on the ground. Working in partnership with the seven local authorities and the Police and Crime Commissioner, I will bid for additional funding to address these urgent needs. Levels of care and access to services should be equally available to all. One of the most pressing issues is mental health, where levels of service and support vary dramatically across the region. I want to ensure that everyone has access to the services they need, including GP Practices. I will work closely with the NHS and Social Care providers to make this a reality. There are too many homes in the region where significant repairs are outstanding, and many properties are affected by black mould and other environmental health threats. I will introduce stringent checks to ensure that existing tenants are living in decent accommodation, and work with Housing Associations to build more affordable homes. There are many former brownfield industrial sites that can be recovered for housing, reducing the need to build on Green Belt land. I will also work with industry to repurpose buildings that are no longer in use, which can be converted into housing accommodation and training centres for the homeless and our service veterans. If elected as your mayor, your hopes, your needs, and your concerns will be my highest priorities. I will act in the best interests of everyone living in the West Midlands Combined Authority region.

Reform will excise the European Convention on Human Rights and the so-called environmental, social and governance (ESG) standards from our national life.

Lee Anderson is a British politician and television presenter currently representing Ashfield as a Member of Parliament (MP). Lee Anderson, born on 6 January 1967 in Ashfield, Nottinghamshire, grew up with his coal miner father and factory worker mother. He attended local schools and was active in Arthur Scargill's National Union of Mineworkers, campaigning for Labour in the 1983 election. Anderson worked as a coal miner for ten years, followed by a decade at Citizens Advice, before supporting homeless care leavers in hostels. Lee Anderson, a long-time Labour Party member, was elected as a Labour councillor in 2015 for Ashfield District's Huthwaite and Brierley ward. In February 2018, he was suspended by Labour after placing boulders to prevent Traveller communities from settling in the area. Following this, Anderson joined the Conservative Party in March 2018, citing dissatisfaction with Labour's shift to the hard left under Momentum. He later served as a Conservative councillor for Mansfield's Oakham ward from 2019 to 2021. On 11 March, Lee Anderson made headlines by joining Reform UK, becoming its first Member of Parliament. Despite previously criticizing the party and its leader, Richard Tice, Anderson's move marked a significant shift. In the 2024 general election, he was re-elected as MP for Ashfield with 42.8% of the vote, though his majority decreased to 5,509. Following the election, Anderson was appointed as Chief Whip of Reform UK. Lee Anderson, a prominent British politician and former Conservative MP, has announced his candidacy as the Reform UK candidate for the Ashfield constituency. Anderson's move to Reform UK reflects growing dissatisfaction among some members of the Conservative Party, particularly with regard to issues such as immigration, economic management, and governmental accountability. His decision to join Reform UK reflects these concerns, as the party continues to advocate for a stronger and more independent Britain. I am a fifty-six-year-old businessman from Chesterfield, married with one grown up son. I was born and bred in Sheffield and have working class roots, which I am proud of. It gave me a firm appreciation of the few things we have and taught me the value of a good honest day's work and getting stuck in, since we had little other choice. There is definitely no silver spoon element here. Everything we have in life is what my wife and I have worked hard for and continue to do so to this day. I have an interest in history and read quite widely. My early working years, between 1987 and 2004, were in finance. I worked for the Prudential Assurance Co, The Midland Bank/HSBC, and then two large accountancy practices in Sheffield servicing business clients. So while I do not claim to be an expert in any of these areas, I believe that those years gave me a decent look behind the scenes at how money works. I have an insight into the world of insurance, savings and investments, banking, accountancy, taxation and how businesses run in general. This is not bad groundwork for any aspiring politician, I guess, and one that gives me perhaps more experience than someone who has just popped out of university with a degree in rocket science. From 2004, I have been running my own vintage motorcycle business. It's a hobby gone mad for me and has been lots of fun. I have met some quite remarkable characters and learnt an awful lot about our automotive history. More importantly I have learnt from hard experience what it takes to survive in business. Being self-employed means you have no sick pay, no holiday pay, no pension plan or cushy benefits such as a company car, medical insurance or an annual Christmas bonus. If you make a mistake in business, you pay for it yourself. This translates to being able to work hard all month and some months finding yourself worse off financially than when you started. Have I had months where I've lost money? Absolutely, and when you're paying personally for waste or mistakes, you learn quick. When your own cash is on the line it is a fine master. It is something many employees never experience, and I feel do not perhaps fully appreciate. Business has also shown me the harsh reality of red tape, of accounts to be done, of VAT returns to be completed, of health and safety, of rates, bills and local government interference, etc. Frankly, small businesses are deluged with hassle. Making a profit is the least of it sometimes. So what have I seen during these last four decades working? Well, the 1987 stock market crash was up close and personal for me. I witnessed the Millennium bug scam unfold followed by the tech stock bubble bursting. I lived through the 2008 banking crises which triggered the recession and the 'austerity years' (have they finished?). We all lived through the surreal lockdowns of the pandemic and most recently the cost-of-living crisis, where everything seems to have doubled in price regardless of reason. It has all been a remarkable financial roller coaster. Working to survive can be hard enough, but when outside forces collude to make all our lives so much harder, I've found myself gnashing my teeth in frustration with everyone else. Which brings me nicely to politics Just like you, I'm sick and tired of powerlessly watching car-crash politics in the UK along with ambulance-chasing politicians who leap on the latest disaster to score some minor political point. I am tired of the weekly Punch and Judy show in Westminster where seemingly 'detached from reality' members score political points off each other across the dispatch box, while the world outside merrily goes to the dogs. I am tired of hearing about (and more pertinently paying for) London's problems or the seeing the country's sole reliance on the one great industry... the city/banking, etc. I am tired of seeing all the other industries being left to whither on the vine. Fishing has been parleyed off, farming is on its knees, mining has gone, steel has gone, shipbuilding has gone, the automotive industry has been sold off or is a shadow of its former self - industry of all types has been actively run down. Even the utilities and trains have been flogged off and run into the ground. We are now apparently just a 'service economy'. Politically, we have had people shouting at each other across the dispatch box in Westminster since Oliver Cromwell established the place in 1650. I have to ask in all seriousness, where has it actually got us? The industrial revolution did not start in Westminster, nor the age of empire, nor the age of remarkable technologies, and even in terms of law-making... how much further on are we than the Magna Carta? All of these started outside the M25 in that strange wider world known as Great Britain, which is where I would like to focus. It is time in my life to start giving a little back and I believe I can add a little value, for what it is worth. Like you, I am sick of not being listened too. I fall down the same potholes as you, pay the same taxes as you and struggle, like you, to survive. I am listening to your problems because I share them. Let's focus on local issues and build jobs and a brighter future here together. What I am seeing and hearing from Reform UK tackles many of these issues. Their policies make sense to me. Common sense. I would be pleased to bring my years of experience to bear on our shared difficulties and listen to your problems. I have my feet on the ground and my head is most definitely not in the clouds. I know that all our lives can be made much better now and I want to pass on a far brighter future to our kids than we are presently on track to do. I believe that it can be done and the choice to roll the dice and take that gamble will be yours come election day. You can choose the same old show or just maybe be brave and give the outsider a fighting chance for once. What have you got to lose? Another lost decade, or a real chance to start fixing the problems with a local representative you can relate too and is really listening.

Richard Tice is a prominent British businessman and politician best known for his role as the leader of Reform UK, a political party formerly known as The Brexit Party. Under Tice's leadership, Reform UK has positioned itself as a key advocate for Brexit, national sovereignty, and economic reform, striving to reshape the political landscape of the United Kingdom. Richard Tice was born on September 13, 1964, and developed an early interest in business and finance. After completing his education at Uppingham School and the University of Salford, where he studied construction economics and quantity surveying, Tice embarked on a successful business career. He quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a high-profile property developer and businessman. Tice co-founded Quidnet Capital Partners, a property investment and development firm. He also held leadership roles in various companies, including the executive chairmanship at CLS Holdings, a FTSE 250 commercial property investment company. His business acumen and leadership skills garnered him a reputation as an influential figure in the UK real estate industry. Tice's political career began as a vocal supporter of the Leave campaign during the 2016 Brexit referendum. His deep commitment to Brexit led him to co-found Leave Means Leave, a cross-party campaign advocating for a full, clean exit from the European Union. His work in promoting Brexit policies brought him into the political spotlight, ultimately leading to his involvement with The Brexit Party. In 2019, Richard Tice was appointed chairman of The Brexit Party, which was founded by Nigel Farage to pressure the UK government into delivering on the Brexit referendum result. Under his leadership, the party won 29 seats in the 2019 European Parliament elections, becoming the largest single party in the European Parliament at the time. Following the formal departure of the UK from the European Union in January 2020, The Brexit Party rebranded itself as Reform UK. Richard Tice took over as the leader of the party in March 2021 after Nigel Farage stepped down. Under his leadership, Reform UK expanded its focus beyond Brexit, advocating for broader political reforms, including tax cuts, deregulation, and the overhaul of the UK's healthcare and education systems. Tice's vision for Reform UK is to challenge the two-party dominance of British politics, promoting policies aimed at economic growth, smaller government, and greater individual freedom. He has been an outspoken critic of lockdowns during the COVID-19 pandemic and has advocated for a more libertarian approach to handling public health crises. As a political leader, Richard Tice is known for his strong media presence, regularly appearing on television, radio, and social media platforms to discuss his party's policies and the future of the UK. He has written for numerous publications and is a frequent commentator on economic and political issues. Richard Tice and Reform UK represent a growing force in British politics, advocating for significant changes in how the country is governed. Tice's leadership, shaped by his business background and commitment to national sovereignty, continues to push for reforms that he believes will make the UK a more prosperous, free, and independent nation. Reform UK aims to attract voters who are disillusioned with the traditional political parties, offering an alternative vision for the country's future. Britain needs successful individuals from business and other sectors to engage in politics to drive meaningful change. By bringing their expertise and leadership skills, these professionals can help improve how the country is run, ensuring that government operations benefit the people rather than serving their own interests. There are numerous areas in the UK that require significant reform, particularly in how the government and civil service function. It's crucial that these institutions work for the people, and not merely serve themselves. The COVID-19 crisis has laid bare many of the shortcomings in the public sector, highlighting the need for strong leadership and decisive action. Stepping into the political arena isn't without its difficulties. Politics can be rough, with its day-to-day challenges and the scrutiny it brings. Beyond the typical hurdles, I've faced other obstacles, including public criticism and legal challenges that emerged after I openly supported Brexit. In 2016, HMRC launched a surprising investigation into my taxes, just as the referendum campaign gained momentum. Despite this scrutiny, the inquiry concluded with me being owed a refund, proving the baseless nature of their investigation. Having done business globally and always fulfilled my tax obligations, the unexpected and aggressive inquiry from HMRC seemed like a targeted response to my political stance. Despite applying to view my HMRC files under the Data Protection Act, I was denied access twice. This lack of transparency raised concerns, but eventually, the investigation confirmed that I had overpaid my taxes. Politics is not always fair. In 2019, I became the subject of false claims from various groups, including a left-wing lobby funded by charities, and even defamatory comments from a Scottish MEP. However, justice prevailed as public apologies were issued and damages were paid to charity. Similarly, BBC Newsnight was forced to retract and apologize for baseless allegations made against me. The 2019 General Election exposed the lengths some media outlets would go to undermine my political candidacy. Channel 4 repeatedly broke election laws in undercover efforts to smear my reputation. Unfortunately, dirty tactics remain a part of traditional politics, even in a democratic country like the UK.

Eddie has no experience of political activism and was just happy to leave it to others, until 2016. He campaigned for Brexit and was betrayed by our politicians. I've watched this country stumble from crisis to crisis, our career politicians only concerned with themselves, lacking common sense, lacking answers, seemingly unaccountable and with a total disconnect with the population. Eddie McDonald was a serving police officer for 30 years with Northamptonshire Police, in every large town and almost every role. Policing provides experiences and a skill set that equiped him to be an effective Member of Parliament. Eddie holds a third Dan black belt in Ju Jitsu and is a qualified personal trainer and he used to help run a martial arts club in Northampton. Eddie has lived in Northamptonshire since 1976 and in the constituency for about ten years, with his wife, who is a schoolteacher. Eddie has four children, all of whom were educated in Corby. Eddie is also frustrated that our Health Service is broken, its mismanaged and for too long has been used as a political football, with the necessary action required to make it a first-class Health Service, put off, for another day. Why can't he and many of you, get an NHS Dentist, or an appointment with a GP when you phone up? Why are our elderly treated as commodities and ignored. Reform and Eddie McDonald will change this. Education is a proven way out of poverty, so why shouldn't we all have the best education, improved facilities and a safe place to learn? Our nation's poorly performing schools need the best teachers to educate, motivate and encourage our children that they can succeed. Eddie will fight for our children's futures and a renewed respect for education. Our Government and Councils continue to mismanage their finances as it's easy to spend someone else's money. Eddie says we elect those who decide how those taxes are spent, its only right that, the Public, hold them to account how they spend our money. Eddie will hold them to account. Increasing Illegal and uncontrolled immigration are having an adverse impact on this country and its infrastructure. An increase of over 10 million people since 2001, resulting in not enough housing, accommodation provided to migrants ahead of vulnerable British people, not able to get a dentist or medical treatment on the NHS, lack of local school places, drain on the Exchequer, increased taxation, and our roads are full of potholes. Reform is the only party that has said it will stop the boats, Reform UK has a plan that involves putting the British People at the centre of everything. Policing and Justice is close to Eddies heart. Do you feel safe in your home or going to the shop? Criminals and the louts, no longer fear being caught, they no longer fear the Police, they no longer fear being punished, they no longer feel community condemnation and they no longer fear Justice. Police Leadership need to get a grip on crimes that impact society, they need to be impartial and our Justice system needs to speed up and get tough on criminals, if we need more jails, build them. Eddie will be tough on criminals and those in the Justice system who fail to share this vision. Justice should be swift and fair, with the victim at the heart of it. Eddie will push for early guilty admissions to be dealt with by the Courts on the day of charge. Trials will be heard even if the defendant fails to turn up to frustrate Justice, this will ensure that Justice is swift, and the victim and witnesses are considered. Eddie also believes we need to invest in our youth, diverting them from a life of crime and to encourage and support our community in challenging this behaviour. It requires a holistic approach with the involvement of local employers, developers, etc. Eddie wants people to be rewarded for their hard work, financial prudence and social responsibility. It's my belief that everyone should contribute to their community to the best of their abilities. The challenges facing us are many and doing the same things, which aren't working again and again, can only be described as stupid and pointless. It's time for change, it's time for Reform.

Scott Cameron is the Reform UK candidate for Daventry, standing for election on July 4th. Scott believes in the need for change and encourages voters to support Reform UK for a fresh approach and a better future for Britain. Scott Cameron is determined to make a difference by challenging the status quo and advocating for sensible policies. With Reform UK, he envisions a path towards a stronger, more effective government. Let's unite and vote for change to make Britain great again!

Born in Derby. I am aged 56 years of age and have lived most of my life in Belper and Duffield where attended Ecclesbourne school for my A levels, now living on a farm in Denby. I am passionate about sports and keeping fit, my main sport is tennis where I reached 47 in the seniors over 45's world rankings and captained England in the Seniors Four Nations competition. I have been despairing at how our country has been run for decades and for the love of my community and country decided that I needed to make a stand and will be trying all I can to be elected to represent and improve the lives of all the people in my constituency.

Pat O'Connor's distinguished career began with 22 years of service in the Army, during which he actively participated in the Falklands War and the Bosnian conflict. Following his military tenure, he dedicated 13 years to Lincolnshire Police. Initially serving as a call taker, Pat managed tens of thousands of calls related to crime in Lincolnshire, gaining valuable insight into community concerns about policing. His subsequent role on the Police committee deepened his understanding of county policing operations, culminating in his position as a Crime Intelligence Analyst specializing in serious sexual offences and domestic violence. Elected to Lincolnshire County Council in 1999, Pat served for 17 years, navigating roles both in control and opposition. His tenure included a significant role as Chairman of the Overview and Scrutiny Committee. Additionally, his four years as a District Councillor saw him appointed as Deputy Leader of West Lindsey District Council and serving as an NHS governor. His commitment to local governance continued as he joined Gainsborough Town Council, where he served as Mayor in 2022/23. Pat's previous parliamentary bid for the Gainsborough seat in 2010 resulted in a strong second place with 27% of the vote. Pat O'Connor's unwavering commitment to community service-evident through his military, police, and council roles-reflects his core ethos. He believes that this dedication stands in contrast to current parliamentary priorities, which he feels have been compromised by woke ideologies and a compliant media. Pat asserts that integrity has diminished due to a lack of accountability, with powerful interests manipulating situations for personal gain. His return to public service is driven by a resolve to address these issues and restore genuine integrity to politics.

Simon's political passion ignited during his involvement with Nigel Farage's campaign at the Peterborough by-election in June 2019, where he also served as a polling station observer. This experience led him to advocate for the phasing out of postal voting, which he views as an unsafe practice. Simon is a staunch supporter of Reform UK, aligning with its strong policies that he believes are crucial for the UK, especially given the shortcomings of the major political parties over the past 40 years. He argues that these parties have misled the public and squandered taxpayer money on an unprecedented scale. In his vision for the NHS, Simon proposes free university tuition for nurses and care workers from day one. He emphasizes that while the NHS does not require complete overhaul, reducing waiting times for treatment to zero is essential. He insists that public funds should ensure value for money in all public services. Simon advocates for green energy projects that must be profitable without government subsidies. He also calls for a return to UK government control over immigration, focusing on genuine cases of those in most need. He criticizes the recent failures of the UK Border Force and insists on prioritizing improvements in this area. As a prospective Member of Parliament, Simon Christy is committed to improving the lives of the people of Gedling. If elected, he promises to remain based within the constituency, reflecting his dedication to local issues.

Mike Rudkin has been a proud resident of Lincolnshire for over 30 years, with deep ancestral ties to the region. Initially moving to the area as a Defence Meteorologist, he has since made Lincolnshire his home, deeply embedding himself in the community. Mike's political journey began during the Brexit campaign, a cause he feels passionately about. Witnessing what he perceives as the mismanagement of the country by the political establishment has inspired him to take action and drive meaningful change. As a staunch advocate for preserving Lincolnshire's rural heritage, Mike is dedicated to maintaining the county's identity as a significant agricultural hub. He is concerned about the local economy's struggles and the increasing pressure on the agricultural industry from financial and regulatory challenges. Mike is committed to defending agricultural land from being repurposed for solar and wind farms and their associated infrastructure. Mike highlights the struggles faced by local NHS services, dentists, and social care providers. He believes that the NHS requires more than temporary fixes and is focused on developing a comprehensive plan to support these essential services. Additionally, he is keenly aware of the need for robust defence, border control, and policing to ensure safety and combat crime. He advocates for a reform of the judicial system to ensure that criminals are held accountable and to address the underfunding and ideological challenges facing the police force. Committed to improving the education system, Mike aims to refocus schools on practical education rather than "woke" ideologies. He believes that removing these distractions will reduce stress for both students and teachers. Furthermore, Mike is dedicated to addressing the issues with the county's road system, including poorly maintained and dangerous roads, and ensuring that government funding for repairs is effectively utilized. Mike is concerned about the impact of new housing developments on local infrastructure, including drainage systems and water supply. He believes that investment is crucial to address these issues and improve services such as public transportation. Under Reform UK, Mike supports reducing taxes and cutting car fuel duty to stimulate the economy. He proposes that the first £20,000 of earnings should be tax-free and aims to lower energy bills by reducing subsidies for green energy projects. Mike is eager to represent the people of Grantham and Bourne, promising to make politics fairer, more representative, and accessible. He invites community members to share their thoughts and support his vision for change. No RAF airfields lie within this constituency, but RAF Cranwell is very near to the border to the north/northeast. Many local people are employed directly or indirectly by the defence sector. There is a small Army barracks just to the North of Grantham (Prince William of Gloucester barracks).

Danuta Jeeves is honored to represent Reform UK as the candidate for the Harborough, Oadby & Wigston constituency in South Leicestershire. With a deep-rooted connection to Leicestershire, Danuta has spent the last 40 years in Whetstone, adjacent to the Harborough constituency. Her extensive experience teaching and engaging with the local community has given her a profound understanding of the area. At 40, Danuta pursued a teaching degree and has since dedicated herself to educating students across Leicestershire and the East Midlands. Danuta's commitment to education and her passion for supporting people from all walks of life underscore her dedication to meaningful change. The party's failure to deliver on Brexit promises and its disregard for manifesto commitments on issues like immigration and public services further fueled her decision to seek change through Reform UK. Her fight for pension equality reflects her broader commitment to social justice. Danuta's decision to join Reform UK is driven by her belief in the party's potential to restore Britain's greatness. She is dedicated to campaigning vigorously across Leicestershire with a dedicated team of Reform UK supporters. Danuta's commitment to advocating for national sovereignty, border control, and cultural identity reflects her resolve to make a tangible difference in British politics. Danuta Jeeves invites you to join her in the mission to "Make Britain Great Again" by supporting Reform UK. With her deep passion and unwavering dedication, Danuta aims to bring about the change needed for a stronger, more unified Britain.

I'm delighted to stand as interim chair of High Peak branch Reform UK and county council candidate for Buxton North and East here in High Peak. I am a local lady, born in Macclesfield as many of us here in the neighbouring hills were, raised in the Staffordshire Moorlands, moved to Derbyshire Dales when I got married in 2004 and have lived in Buxton spa town here in High Peak for the last 5 years with my husband Paul and our children. I am new to politics although my interest in current affairs is long-standing. I have voted for both Labour and Conservative candidates at different general elections, but over recent years I have tended to favour the more independent-thinking parties like UKIP, the Brexit Party and now Reform UK. Like many others, I decided to back Reform UK because it is a party full of common-sense people with common-sense ideas, and candidates who are motivated to stand because we believe in putting Britain and our voters first. I am doing my utmost to build our local branch to give the people of High Peak a political voice, both locally in May 2025 and nationally in 2029. If you live in High Peak and you want to join our branch and the people's army, get in touch with me today.

Prior to retirement, my career was in Surveying and I spent many years in Local Government managing a team of surveyors. My interests include live entertainment (I am a patron of the Concordia Theatre), discovering new places with my touring caravan, and reading railway and social history. I also support local animal rescue organizations, and I have adopted several older rescue dogs. I love my country and I am not happy with the way it is being governed. I hold the strong belief that we are a sovereign and island nation, and that we should not be governed by any foreign court or organization. I recognize that the inevitable cycle of alternating Team Red and Team Blue at Westminster is a cycle doomed to failure. Both parties have proved unreliable, and both are distracted by interminable and counter-productive internal disagreements. Over the years, neither party has proved willing or capable of offering what we, the electorate, wants and voted for. Owing to this regrettable state of affairs, today it is difficult to find anything in our country which is not broken or which is still fit for purpose. For example - Border Control, the Police, the N.H.S., the Economy, suitable support for Veterans, Cost of Living, Pensions, Employment, Education, etc. The current High Tax and Low Growth policy is unsustainable, and we are seeing our country and our way of life being ruined. We are a democracy, but we are not getting the government that we deserve. Reform UK is the alternative that can help us to achieve a better life. Through Reform UK, I want to help turn our country around. To stop the rot. To bring back prosperity to our country. To mend broken Britain. I am standing as a candidate for Reform UK, because it is the only party that recognizes that we need to examine all our main institutions and work out how they can be restructured and revitalized to meet our needs and how these changes can realistically be financed - as detailed in our equivalent of a manifesto called 'Our Contract with You' on the party website. As your Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Hinckley and Bosworth Constituency, I consider myself very fortunate to have this opportunity to work towards these goals. I believe we can save Britain and make our lives better. A vote for Reform UK is a vote for change - change for the better. An M.P. has an important role in national government, but also has a duty to represent all constituents at a local level. I have lived in Barwell for the past 8 years, so I have genuine local knowledge of the main concerns and problems we face in the constituency where I am standing for election. I know, for example, that there are particular issues concerning the expansion of towns and villages without the infrastructure and facilities being upgraded, thus increasing the pressure on the existing infrastructure and facilities, the present planning system is broken, it ignores cumulative effect of developments and the true need for major road improvements, new schools and G.P. Surgeries, I shall do my best to fight for a common sense, fair and balanced revision of the Planning Laws. I became active in mainstream politics when the Brexit Party was formed. I became a member, and later held the position of Bosworth Constituency Coordinator. When the Brexit Party became Reform UK, I transferred my membership. I have previously served for 10 years as an independent parish councilor, recently I have been a candidate for Reform UK in both the County Council and Borough Council Elections. Now I am hoping that you will support me to act for you on a national level as your Constituency M.P., because, to quote our party, 'Britain needs Reform and Reform needs You'. It can be done, and I really believe we can do it.

Crispian Besley boasts a distinguished career as a former Managing Director at one of the largest global investment banks. Crispian Besley is not driven by personal ambition but by a genuine desire to serve the country and its hardworking citizens. Besley is a strong advocate for a bottom-up political approach that is more open and accessible, opposing the influence of undemocratic global organizations on national institutions. Crispian Besley believes that Reform UK is poised to replace the Tories and stand as a genuine opposition. He advocates for a party that upholds British values, culture, and identity, with a focus on restoring pride and greatness to Britain. For those seeking real change, Besley urges voters to choose Reform UK over the traditional parties.

Craig Harwood proudly represents Leicester South as the Reform Party candidate. Jamie-Lee McMillan joined ReformUK after observing that traditional parties-Labour, Conservatives, Liberal Democrats, Greens-seemed indistinguishable in his actions and policies, differing only in his chosen colours. Jamie notes that these parties fail to uphold the policies and promises they campaign on, often adopting policies that appear deceptive or anti-democratic. Jamie-Lee found ReformUK to be a party that not only supports his views, but also inspires them. Jamie values the party's commitment to a new direction for Britain, characterized by genuine concern for the nation's future and a compassionate leadership approach. ReformUK represents a refreshing contrast to the conventional political landscape, embodying a vision for a better future. Jamie-Lee McMillan, the PPC for Lincoln, was raised in Sleaford and now resides near RAF Waddington. He is eager to connect with and represent her community, looking forward to engaging with constituents and advocating for meaningful change.

Andy McWilliam was raised in Cheshire and Kent, later graduating with a Bachelor of Dental Surgery from the University of Newcastle upon Tyne. For the past 44 years, he has lived in Charnwood, primarily practicing dentistry in Leicester, as well as in Shepshed and Barrow upon Soar. He is married to Mary and is now retired, but continues to enjoy a range of interests, including cycling, hill walking, languages, music, sailing, DIY projects, travel, and politics. Andy's political journey began in 2011 when he joined UKIP in response to the lack of an EU referendum. He served as the chairman of the UKIP Loughborough & District branch from 2013 to 2018, and ran for UKIP in the 2015 General Election, securing 17% of the vote in North West Leicestershire. In 2016, he was a key figure in Loughborough's BREXIT campaign, working with various political groups. In 2017, Andy stood for UKIP again in Loughborough as a democracy candidate. After joining The Brexit Party in 2018, he campaigned vigorously until December 2019. In 2021, he became the East & West Midlands area manager for Reform UK, and in 2022, he was appointed County Organiser for Leicestershire & Rutland. Now, in 2024, Andy is standing as a Parliamentary candidate for the Loughborough constituency. Andy is deeply concerned about the unsustainable population growth in the UK, which he sees as a fundamental issue driving many national challenges. He advocates for strict immigration controls and a focus on balancing population numbers to ensure a sustainable future. A strong believer in free speech, Andy supports policies grounded in common sense and real-world solutions. He is dedicated to ensuring that political discourse remains open and balanced, valuing reason over political correctness. Andy is critical of globalisation, believing it has contributed to a loss of national sovereignty and weakened the UK's position in the world. He seeks to bring control back to the UK, ensuring that decisions impacting the country are made domestically rather than being influenced by global forces. Andy believes some UK institutions have become overreaching and inefficient. He advocates for significant reforms to bring these bodies back in line with the needs and expectations of the British people. As a candidate for Loughborough, Andy's vision includes achieving a complete BREXIT where UK laws fully govern the country. He supports net-zero immigration with a "one in, one out" policy, allowing entry for essential skills that cannot be readily trained domestically. He advocates for an immigration system that ensures those arriving illegally are processed offshore and returned if they reject the legal route. In addition, Andy calls for an energy policy that strengthens UK industry, reducing reliance on foreign economies such as China and India. He is critical of the current "Net Zero" policy, labeling it "Net Stupid" due to its perceived negative impact on UK economic growth. Andy argues for the integration of cultures based on English values, laws, and language, stating that while every culture matters, the primary focus should be on English identity. He sees multiculturalism as creating division and believes a unified national identity is essential. He also emphasizes that Loughborough's housing challenges are not a result of a housing shortage but rather a population crisis. To address this, Andy seeks long-term solutions to manage population growth and ensure adequate housing supply for future generations.

Sean Matthews is honored to have been selected as the Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Louth and Horncastle, representing Reform UK. With a strong background in public service and a deep commitment to his community, Sean is ready to bring his passion for reform and change to Parliament. Sean's journey began with his service in the Metropolitan Police, where he joined in 1993. Throughout his career, he worked across various boroughs and specialist departments, gaining extensive experience and insight into the communities he served. His time as a family liaison officer, dealing with bereaved families, was especially formative, shaping his belief in the importance of compassion, care, and living fully in the present. In 2018, after a fulfilling career, Sean retired and moved to Lincolnshire to be closer to his family. His decision to settle just outside Horncastle was driven by his desire for his younger children to enjoy the wide open space of the countryside. Today, Sean is a proud father of four, with his eldest daughter living in Lincoln and expecting his third grandchild, while his younger children are thriving in local schools. Since retiring, Sean has thrown himself into local politics and community activities. He has stood in both district and county elections and has been actively involved in running election campaigns. He was also the chairman of his local parish meeting, demonstrating his ongoing commitment to serving his community. A dedicated rugby fan, Sean is actively involved in the sport, having coached his sons and regularly attending games. In his spare time, he enjoys golf and is pursuing a master's degree in Politics, Philosophy, and Economics, reigniting his passion for education. Sean's political journey took a significant turn when he decided to leave the Conservative Party. Once a local branch chair and a member of the association's executive, he grew disillusioned with the party's shift towards a left-wing agenda. The continuous changes in leadership, culminating in the election of Rishi Sunak as Prime Minister, led Sean to resign and join Reform UK. Now, Sean is determined to represent Reform UK and its policies, which he believes offer the best solutions for the challenges Britain faces today. From low taxes and zero immigration to affordable energy and cutting down waiting lists, Reform UK provides a clear, practical alternative to the two main parties. Sean firmly believes it is time to break the two-party deadlock that has failed the country. With a vision to reform immigration policies, the public sector, and institutions like the BBC and the House of Lords, Sean is committed to making a real difference. He hopes the people of Louth and Horncastle will take a bold step by electing him as their MP and support Reform UK's mission to rebuild and strengthen Britain. Running a successful election campaign requires significant resources, and Sean is asking for support from those who believe in Reform UK's vision. Contributions, big or small, can help him in his mission to bring real change to Louth and Horncastle.

Matt Warnes is honored to stand as a candidate for the Reform Party, driven by a deep commitment to his community and a passion for positive change. With a diverse professional background and strong ties to Mansfield, Matt is dedicated to addressing the issues facing the town and working towards a brighter future. With a background in healthcare training and support, Matt has developed a strong understanding of compassionate care. He has worked extensively with carers, preparing them to support young adults with autism, ensuring they are equipped with the necessary skills to serve this important community. As a Heavy Goods Vehicle (HGV) driver, Matt witnessed the challenges drivers face in the industry, including the penalties imposed on them. His firsthand experience has given him a deep understanding of the issues hindering new drivers from entering the field, contributing to rising consumer costs. Matt proudly served in the Royal Air Force (RAF), where he developed exceptional leadership abilities and a commitment to excellence. His military background has equipped him with the discipline and strategic thinking that are invaluable in both his professional and community roles. Supporting service members and veterans is one of Matt's top priorities, as he believes it's time to stop leaving our heroes behind. In addition to these roles, Matt has run his own non-profit business, helping children from all walks of life celebrate their dream parties. His organization is widely recognized for its charitable efforts, supporting schools, fundraisers, and individuals across the community. Matt is a passionate advocate for inclusivity and community empowerment. His active involvement in various local initiatives demonstrates his commitment to creating a supportive environment for all. As a devoted father to a child with cerebral palsy, Matt has gained a unique perspective on the challenges families face and is deeply committed to making a positive impact on the world around him. Born in Mansfield's Kings Mill Hospital and raised in Blidworth, Matt attended Joseph Whitaker School before joining the RAF at 19. His deep connection to Mansfield fuels his dedication to its future. For years, he has worked tirelessly to serve the town, striving to uphold its core values and make it a better place for families to live, work, and thrive. He calls for the working people of Mansfield to take a stand, rejecting career politicians who prioritize personal gain over the needs of the community. Peter Morris, originally from Melton Mowbray, began his education at Edmondthorpe and Melton schools. Peter Morris later acquired a lifting gear company in Loughborough, effectively managing both enterprises until his retirement. His entrepreneurial success was marked by his ability to oversee and grow his businesses in a competitive industry. Peter's political journey began with his involvement in Brexit-related campaigns, where he actively supported efforts in Stoke on Trent, Peterborough, Derby, Leicester, Loughborough, and surrounding areas. His commitment extended to standing for local and county council elections with Reform UK and contributing to by-elections in Mid Bedford and Tamworth. Peter Morris is deeply concerned about the influence of globalist billionaires on cultural and societal values. Over the past three years, he has dedicated significant time to researching connections between the pandemic, vaccine issues, and the World Economic Forum's agenda, often referred to as The Great Reset. His research reflects his commitment to addressing perceived threats to heritage, freedom, and way of life.

Stephen Dean was born in Nottingham, a city rich in history and culture. Growing up in this vibrant area, he became well-acquainted with the city's connection to Derby via the Brian Clough Way (A52), highlighting the link between these two prominent East Midlands cities. Stephen's career spans sales and marketing, with a recent focus on technical roles. He began his professional life during the height of the Blair reform era, a period marked by a shift of monetary power from individuals to large corporations. This shift allowed supermarkets to dominate, leading to the decline of many town centers. During this era, Stephen witnessed new global conflicts and constitutional reforms that increasingly concentrated power in the hands of financial corporate bodies. He attributes many of the nation's issues to self-interest and profiteering, such as the ongoing human trafficking problem in the Channel, which he believes could be resolved by nationalizing Serco. Stephen critiques Blairism for consolidating power within wealthy corporate circles, leveraging well-intentioned individuals on the left to create policies that are often mirrored by the Conservative party. He observes that Conservative policies frequently have roots in Labour party ideas, reflecting a lack of genuine change. Stephen is honored to represent Reform UK as a candidate for Mid Derbyshire. He is driven by the desire to address the intolerable state of the nation, where basic needs like housing are unmet, and the cycle of Conservative-Labour administrations perpetuates increasing hardship for ordinary people. Stephen believes that the nation feels oppressed and that its culture is diverging from traditional English values. Tom Smith, formally known as Thomas Patrick Smith, is proud to represent Reform UK as a candidate. Witnessing numerous strikes and disputes during this period, he became a union representative at seventeen. This role not only deepened his understanding of political dynamics but also provided him with valuable experience in representing and assisting individuals through disciplinary and mediation processes. Continuing his career within the NHS, Tom trained as a nurse at De Montfort University and was elected as a cohort representative in 1999. He advanced to the role of charge nurse and later became a senior prison nurse, dedicating 22 years to the NHS. Tom is passionate about Reform UK's mission and aims to address various challenges facing the nation. He believes that the NHS has suffered under ineffective management strategies that prioritize financial investment and additional bureaucracy rather than meaningful reform. He advocates for locally trained professionals in government roles and supports initiatives that encourage apprenticeships and skill development among youth. In his bid for the Mid Leicestershire (formerly Charnwood) constituency, Tom is committed to preserving the local environment and heritage. He is concerned about the impacts of uncontrolled immigration, including increased housing costs, reduced land for farming, deteriorating public services, and fewer job opportunities for residents. Tom is critical of current government policies on Net Zero, highlighting practical challenges such as the inadequacy of electric vehicle charging infrastructure. He also advocates for maintaining agricultural land, opposing the conversion of farmland into wind or solar farms that drive up utility bills before installation. Tom Smith is determined to make Britain great again and to advocate for the interests of Mid Leicestershire. He believes that Reform UK offers a necessary change from the status quo and urges voters to support the party for a positive future. Tom extends his gratitude to the Mid Leicestershire election team and all Reform UK supporters for their dedication and support. He invites the voters of Mid Leicestershire to join the movement and be part of the change that will "MAKE BRITAIN GREAT.".

Robert Hall-Palmer is deeply committed to the idea of reform, particularly in reversing the changes introduced by the Labour government under Tony Blair. He believes that the current funding model is outdated and unfair, and he advocates for a more modern approach to public broadcasting that better reflects the needs and preferences of today's citizens. Robert Hall-Palmer argues for restoring Parliament's veto power, enabling it to respond swiftly and effectively to pressing issues, such as the migrant crisis. He believes that re-empowering Parliament is crucial for maintaining the sovereignty and integrity of the UK's governance. Robert is a vocal critic of Net Zero policies, viewing them as a dangerous and misguided ideology that could cause significant harm. He points to the recent skepticism from the UAE and Russia at COP28, which questioned the scientific consensus on climate change. Robert believes that, given the lack of global agreement on the origins of hydrocarbons, humanity is not equipped to create accurate climate models or predict future changes. He emphasizes that all existing climate models share a common flaw-their consistent failure to predict climate changes accurately. For Robert, this inconsistency calls into question the reliability of current climate science and the policies based on it. He advocates for a more cautious and evidence-based approach to environmental policy.

Chris Clowes is dedicated to protecting the unique character of Rutland, Stamford, and the surrounding areas he represents. Growing up near Billesdon, Clowes enjoyed the area's stunning landscapes and historic towns. He fondly recalls traditions like the Medbourne-Hallaton bottlekicking on Easter Monday and local point-to-point races as cherished memories. Clowes has actively volunteered to support the elderly and disabled, learning firsthand the importance of community in the face of sweeping changes. As a motorsport engineer, Clowes is critical of Labour councils that impose ULEZ regulations and speed restrictions, which he argues are unscientific and detrimental to working people. He views these restrictions as a tax on freedom and is determined to prevent their expansion into Stamford and Rutland. Clowes recognizes that small businesses are the backbone of Rutland and is committed to advocating for legislation that would alleviate tax burdens on these businesses. He believes that small shops on the high street are unfairly penalized compared to larger enterprises, which contributes to their closures. By addressing excessive running costs and high energy bills, Clowes aims to support local retailers and ensure a vibrant high street. Clowes emphasizes the need to protect the rich history of the constituency, including landmarks such as the Normanton Church on Rutland Water and the site of Isaac Newton's apple tree. He expresses frustration with Tory policies that he believes undermine rural interests while prioritizing metropolitan concerns. He criticizes the government's handling of the Mallard Pass Solar Farm and calls for greater support for farmers, arguing against the trend towards large-scale, impersonal farming operations. Through his efforts, Chris Clowes seeks to ensure that the values and heritage of Rutland and Stamford are preserved for future generations, despite the challenges posed by current policies and developments.

Reform UK, previously known as the Brexit Party, continues to push for fundamental changes in the way the UK is governed, focusing on issues such as immigration control, economic reform, and greater governmental transparency. Nigel Farage has had a long and impactful career in British politics. He is best known for his leadership of UKIP, a party that gained significant traction in the early 2000s as it campaigned for the United Kingdom to leave the European Union. Farage's charisma and persistence played a major role in shifting the debate over Britain's EU membership from the fringes to the mainstream. In 2016, he was instrumental in the successful Leave campaign, which resulted in the UK voting to exit the EU. Although he never won a seat in the House of Commons, Farage's influence was undeniable. He was a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) for over two decades and used his platform to advocate for national sovereignty and British independence from Brussels. After the Brexit referendum, Farage stepped down from the leadership of UKIP, though he continued to be an influential figure in British politics. He later founded the Brexit Party, which morphed into Reform UK after the UK officially left the EU, aiming to push for reforms in the political system that Farage and his supporters felt were still necessary. Clacton, located on the Essex coast, is a constituency with a unique political history. It was represented by Douglas Carswell, a former Conservative MP who famously defected to UKIP in 2014, becoming the first MP elected to Parliament under the UKIP banner. This made Clacton a symbol of the growing support for euroscepticism and a desire for political change, particularly in working-class coastal areas that felt left behind by mainstream parties. Given Clacton's history and its strong support for Brexit, Farage's candidacy is seen as a natural fit. The constituency voted overwhelmingly to leave the European Union in 2016, and many voters remain dissatisfied with how the government has handled the post-Brexit landscape. Farage, with his deep association with Brexit and his consistent stance on reducing immigration and reclaiming national sovereignty, speaks to these frustrations. As a Reform UK candidate, Farage's platform in Clacton will focus on several core issues. Immigration control remains one of his central themes, as Farage has long argued that unchecked immigration is damaging the fabric of British society and placing immense pressure on public services like the NHS and schools. He advocates for a points-based immigration system to ensure that only individuals with skills beneficial to the UK economy can settle in the country. In Clacton, where there are concerns about job competition and access to services, this message is likely to resonate. Economic reform is another major aspect of Farage's campaign. Clacton, like many parts of coastal Britain, has faced economic challenges, including unemployment and underinvestment. Farage argues that lowering taxes, reducing bureaucracy, and incentivizing business investment are necessary steps to revive local economies. He also supports the idea of free ports, which could offer tax breaks and boost trade in areas like Clacton, driving economic growth and job creation. Farage is also campaigning for a political system overhaul. Reform UK believes that the current system is broken, with both major parties-Labour and the Conservatives-failing to represent ordinary citizens. Farage advocates for proportional representation, which he argues would lead to a more democratic and accountable political system. Nigel Farage's candidacy for the Clacton constituency as a Reform UK candidate is a significant moment for both him and the party. His long-standing leadership in the Brexit movement, combined with his new focus on political and economic reform, makes him a strong contender in a constituency that has historically supported eurosceptic views. With a platform focused on immigration control, economic regeneration, and political reform, Farage's campaign offers Clacton voters a familiar but revitalized choice for representation in Parliament. His candidacy signals not just a return to the political frontline for Farage, but also a renewed push for Reform UK's vision of a transformed Britain.

Terence Longstaff was born in Colchester and spent his early years moving frequently due to his father's military career. After settling back in Colchester, he completed his secondary education. Upon retiring from the Army, Terence transitioned to a new career as an Engineering Operations Manager, specializing in maintaining plant operations for wastewater sites. In his current position, Terence has gained valuable insights into the environmental challenges posed by outdated infrastructure. He is particularly concerned about the pollution affecting waterways and beaches due to the inability of old systems to handle the increasing number of residential connections. Terence advocates for a reform in how water companies allocate their profits, urging them to invest in modern equipment rather than merely paying fines for environmental breaches. Terence Longstaff has been married to Sharon for 32 years. The couple has three children and one grandson. In their leisure time, Terence and Sharon enjoy dog walks and motorbike rides through the county's picturesque lanes. They relish the opportunity to explore and unwind, often stopping for refreshments along the way while navigating the local potholes.

Harry Palmer is proud to have been selected as the Reform UK candidate for Dunstable and Leighton Buzzard, driven by a deep belief in Britain and a commitment to real change. In an era of rising taxes, government overspending, and uncontrolled immigration, Palmer sees only one path forward - Reform UK. Unlike the traditional parties, which have become indistinguishable, Reform UK stands for bold, necessary action to address the issues facing the nation. Palmer believes the people deserve an alternative to the status quo. Reform UK offers the solutions that other parties avoid, from tackling the cost-of-living crisis to restoring control over immigration. As Reform UK's PPC (Prospective Parliamentary Candidate) for Dunstable and Leighton Buzzard, Harry Palmer is committed to ensuring that British values and common sense guide policy decisions. Harry Palmer believes that the British people deserve to keep more of their hard-earned money. One of his key proposals is raising the income tax threshold from £12,571 to £20,000, ensuring that people are incentivized to return to work and improve their financial well-being. "Change won't happen until you vote for change," Palmer emphasizes. He invites the community to join the movement, volunteer, and help campaign for a better Britain. For those eager to make a difference, Palmer is ready to lead the charge for Reform UK and put the nation on a path to progress.

Ryan Coogan, originally from the Fenland town of Soham, moved there in 1989 and attended The Weatheralls School, Soham Village College, and later Hills Road College in Cambridge. He worked his way up through companies like Xerox and Sainsbury's, including a notable role in the team that opened the Sainsbury's store in Ely. His career also includes extensive experience in healthcare, retail, transport, biofuels, and renewable energy power stations. A passionate sports enthusiast, Coogan played at a high level in his youth. His commitment to community service extends to voluntary roles such as working with the Kings Theatre in Newmarket and serving as a volunteer water bailiff for the Angling Trust.
